UtiliPoint Interviews Chuck Vermillion About OneNeck's Acquisition of Delinea (UtiliPoint.com - Apr. 23, 2007) 



UtiliPoint.com - Apr. 23, 2007 - In early February of this year OneNeck IT Services, an ERP hosting services company focused on mid-market companies, acquired Dallas-based Delinea, a company specializing in Oracle ERP and other consulting opportunities existing in the energy and utilities industries.

NATIONAL NEWS






Choosing plan is daunting, even for business reporter



Apr. 22--I don't recall making the conscious choice to stick with TXU as my electricity provider when I became a homeowner two years ago. What I remember is simply calling TXU and asking them to turn on the lights in my new home.  I briefly reconsidered that decision when I got my first bill at the new house: $141.57 for 1,273 kilowatt-hours of electricity over six days.


Apr 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Austin Utilities tries to form gas agency



Apr. 23--Austin Utilities hopes by June to be part of a new natural-gas agency that will help it control costs.  Austin Utilities General Manager Jerry McCarthy announced during a recent city council meeting that Austin Utilities is one of about 31 municipal utilities in Minnesota planning to join together as a gas agency. The council voted to approve a resolution in support of Austin Utilities ...


Apr 23, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Lower Ark Valley banking on renewable energy bounce



Apr. 22--LAMAR -- Southeastern Colorado is seeing some pretty tough times in its battle with Mother Nature.  There's an ongoing drought that is drying farm and ranch lands; two blizzards buried the area, killing about 10,000 cattle in late December; and a lethal tornado whipped the town of Holly just last month. With all the obstacles laid in front of them, area leaders and residents are looking ...


Apr 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Power rate surges haven't hit here just yet



Apr. 22--The huge price increases power customers in Illinois are experiencing haven't hit the Pittsburgh market, but have come close.  Within Duquesne Light Co.'s service territory of Allegheny and portions of Beaver counties, rate caps expired in 2002, but residential electricity prices are lower than they were prior to deregulation in 1996. "The cost of contracts entered into by Duquesne (to ...

Earth Day: Measuring Progress: Tulsa given low marks: 50 largest cities ranked by sustainability factors



Apr. 22--Slide show: Watch a slide show of all the photographs released by NASA. Sunday is Earth Day, but should Tulsa be celebrating? Tulsa ranks 40th out of the top 50 most populous U.S. cities in a recent report on efforts to improve the environment. The ranking is based on factors such as traffic congestion, air quality, housing affordability and natural disaster risk -- all of which Tulsa ...

Durbin praises windfarms



Apr. 22--ELLSWORTH -- Renewable energy sources produce more than electricity -- they also produce jobs and boost the local economy, U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin told a group Saturday at the Twin Groves Wind Farm.  With spinning wind turbines as a backdrop for the Earth Day visit, the Illinois Democrat told a small group of wind energy supporters that they can expect action in Washington, D.C., in the ...


Apr 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News





Maryland joins greenhouse coalition



Maryland has joined a multi-state effort to curb global warming by cutting carbon dioxide emissions from power plants. Gov. Martin O'Malley cited the potential threat global warming and rising sea levels pose to his state's coastline as a reason to join the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. The initiative will create a cap-and-trade scheme for CO2 emissions beginning in 2009.


Apr 22, 2007 PhysOrg.com



>> Power Bills Soar As Electric Deregulation Fails to Live Up to Its Promises



AP IMPACT: Power Bills Soar As Electric Deregulation Fails to Live Up to Its Promises Ryan Keith BENTON, Ill. (AP) - This wasn't supposed to happen with deregulation. Electric bills were supposed to go down. Instead, Ellie Dorchincez can almost see the dollars evaporating every time she turns on the lights or opens the freezer at her small Farm Fresh grocery store.

Fighting for the right to pay for our power



PS writes: Unlike most of your correspondents, who want to recover or avoid making payments, we actually want to pay our power supplier Npower but are unable to do so. The residents association you represent had been trying for months to get a proper bill from Npower. The root of this problem was that the managing agents of the property concerned had changed, and the bills were no longer being ...

ODS-Petrodata Launches First Phase of Energy Current Online News Service



ODS-Petrodata, the leading provider of news, data and consulting services specific to the offshore oil and gas industry, has launched Energy Current(TM), a new online news service offering global coverage of targeted energy industry segments. Now online at http://www.energycurrent.com , Energy Current provides timely, accurate in-depth news and analysis on the global energy industry.

Apr 19, 2007 Internet Wire



Wind farm threatened by climate penalty



A wind farm development near Wellington has been threatened by Government climate change proposals that could add a $1.5 million penalty for chopping down 'junky' pine trees. Under climate change discussion papers published earlier this year, the Government proposed a series of measures to discourage deforestation, including tradeable permits and flat charges for tree removal.


Apr 19, 2007 Dominion Post



Boxer will 'hound' Bush on emissions regulations



(04-19) 04:00 PDT Washington -- Sen. Barbara Boxer promised to pressure the Bush administration to adopt California-style global warming regulations, saying Wednesday that the Supreme Court 'handed us a gift' with its recent landmark decision authorizing the Environmental Protection Agency to reduce greenhouse gases as a pollutant. The decision 'put the wind at our backs,' the California Democrat ...
